mn103:0.2.eng: Is This What You Think Of Me?

mn103:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā pisinārāyaṃ viharati baliharaṇe vanasaṇḍe.
mn103:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusinārā, in the Forest of Offerings.

mn103:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn103:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, is this what you think of me?

mn103:2.2.pli: ‘cīvarahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, piṇḍapātahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, senāsanahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, itibhavābhavahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ desetī’”ti?
mn103:2.2.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama teaches the Dhamma for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.’”
mn103:2.2.comm: Bhavābhava does not mean “existence and non-existence” but is a distributive compound, “this or that state of existence”. Indian religious texts are full of discussions about different heavens and hells. The Buddha’s goal is liberation, not rebirth in heaven.

mn103:2.3.pli: “Na kho no, bhante, bhagavati evaṃ hoti:
mn103:2.3.eng: “No sir, we don’t think of you that way.”

mn103:2.4.pli: ‘cīvarahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, piṇḍapātahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, senāsanahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti, itibhavābhavahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ desetī’”ti.

mn103:2.5.pli: “Na ca kira vo, bhikkhave, mayi evaṃ hoti:
mn103:2.5.eng: “If you don’t think of me that way,

mn103:2.7.pli: itibhavābhavahetu vā samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ desetī’ti;

mn103:2.8.pli: atha kinti carahi vo, bhikkhave, mayi hotī”ti?
mn103:2.8.eng: what then do you think of me?”

mn103:2.10.eng: ‘The Buddha is sympathetic and wants what’s best for us.

mn103:2.14.eng: that I teach out of sympathy.

mn103:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ye vo mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, seyyathidaṃ—
mn103:3.1.eng: In that case, each and every one of you should train in the things I have taught from my direct knowledge, that is:

mn103:3.2.pli: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañcindriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjhaṅgā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, tattha sabbeheva samaggehi sammodamānehi avivadamānehi sikkhitabbaṃ.
mn103:3.2.eng: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path. You should train in these things in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute.
mn103:3.2.comm: These are the sets of practices later called the 37 bodhiyapakkhiyā dhammā, the “wings to awakening”. Here they are presented as an essential summary of the Buddha’s teachings. They form the backbone of the final book of the Saṁyuttanikāya, the Maggavagga (or Mahāvagga). It is likely that the Buddha was referring to the earliest recension of this text. They are found as a summary of the Buddha’s teachings at DN 16:3.50.5, DN 29:17.3, MN 104:5.3, and AN 8.19:17.2 = Ud 5.5:25.2.

mn103:4.1.pli: Tesañca vo, bhikkhave, samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ siyaṃsu dve bhikkhū abhidhamme nānāvādā.
mn103:4.1.eng: As you do so, it may happen that two mendicants disagree about the teaching.

mn103:5.2.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho āyasmantānaṃ atthato ceva nānaṃ byañjanato ca nānan’ti, tattha yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:5.2.eng: ‘These two venerables disagree on both the meaning and the phrasing.’ So you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable and say to them:
mn103:5.2.comm: “Meaning” is attha, the “purpose”, “goal”, or “benefit” of the teaching. “Phrasing is byañjana (also spelled vyañjana), the “letter”, “syllable”, or “expression”, with the root sense of “differentiating”. Such passages show that concern for both aspects were present from the earliest times. | “Most amenable” is suvacatara, literally, “more easy to speak to”.

mn103:5.3.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato ceva nānaṃ, byañjanato ca nānaṃ.
mn103:5.3.eng: ‘The venerables disagree on the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:5.4.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:5.5.pli: yathā atthato ceva nānaṃ, byañjanato ca nānaṃ.
mn103:5.5.eng: such disagreement on the meaning and the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:5.6.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:5.7.pli: Athāparesaṃ ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:5.7.eng: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:

mn103:5.8.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato ceva nānaṃ, byañjanato ca nānaṃ.
mn103:5.8.eng: ‘The venerables disagree on the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:5.9.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:5.10.pli: yathā atthato ceva nānaṃ, byañjanato ca nānaṃ.
mn103:5.10.eng: such disagreement on the meaning and the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:5.11.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:5.12.pli: Iti duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretabbaṃ, suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretabbaṃ.
mn103:5.12.eng: So you should remember what has been incorrectly memorized as incorrectly memorized and what has been correctly memorized as correctly memorized.
mn103:5.12.comm: When the source of the problem has been identified, it should be remembered so that it does not recur.

mn103:5.13.pli: Duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretvā suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretvā yo dhammo yo vinayo so bhāsitabbo.
mn103:5.13.eng: Remembering this, you should speak on the teaching and the training.

mn103:6.2.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho āyasmantānaṃ atthato hi kho nānaṃ, byañjanato sametī’ti, tattha yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:6.2.eng: ‘These two venerables disagree on the meaning but agree on the phrasing.’ So you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable and say to them:
mn103:6.2.comm: At AN 6.61:10.5 we see a group of monks discussing a verse of the Dhamma, with different interpretations, and the Buddha praises them as having all spoken well. Thus it is not that any different interpretation is wrong, but that some different interpretations conflict with the fundamental purpose of the teaching, the attha.

mn103:6.3.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato hi nānaṃ, byañjanato sameti.
mn103:6.3.eng: ‘The venerables disagree on the meaning but agree on the phrasing.

mn103:6.4.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:6.5.pli: yathā atthato hi kho nānaṃ, byañjanato sameti.
mn103:6.5.eng: such disagreement on the meaning and agreement on the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:6.6.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:6.7.pli: Athāparesaṃ ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:6.7.eng: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:

mn103:6.8.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato hi kho nānaṃ, byañjanato sameti.
mn103:6.8.eng: ‘The venerables disagree on the meaning but agree on the phrasing.

mn103:6.9.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:6.10.pli: yathā atthato hi kho nānaṃ, byañjanato sameti.
mn103:6.10.eng: such disagreement on the meaning and agreement on the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:6.11.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:6.12.pli: Iti duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretabbaṃ, suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretabbaṃ.
mn103:6.12.eng: So you should remember what has been incorrectly memorized as incorrectly memorized and what has been correctly memorized as correctly memorized.

mn103:6.13.pli: Duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretvā suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretvā yo dhammo yo vinayo so bhāsitabbo.
mn103:6.13.eng: Remembering this, you should speak on the teaching and the training.

mn103:7.2.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho āyasmantānaṃ atthato hi kho sameti, byañjanato nānan’ti, tattha yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:7.2.eng: ‘These two venerables agree on the meaning but disagree on the phrasing.’ So you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable and say to them:

mn103:7.3.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato hi sameti, byañjanato nānaṃ.
mn103:7.3.eng: ‘The venerables agree on the meaning but disagree on the phrasing.

mn103:7.4.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:7.5.pli: yathā atthato hi kho sameti, byañjanato nānaṃ.
mn103:7.5.eng: such agreement on the meaning and disagreement on the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:7.6.eng: But the phrasing is a minor matter.
mn103:7.6.comm: One of the reasons why the phrasing is considered less important is that the Buddhist texts are constructed with a massive amount of redundancy. In any question of significance, a variation in a phrase or a word in one place is almost always clarified with reference to another passage.

mn103:7.7.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about something so minor.’

mn103:7.8.pli: Athāparesaṃ ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:7.8.eng: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:

mn103:7.9.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato hi sameti, byañjanato nānaṃ.
mn103:7.9.eng: ‘The venerables agree on the meaning but disagree on the phrasing.

mn103:7.10.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:7.11.pli: yathā atthato hi kho sameti, byañjanato nānaṃ.
mn103:7.11.eng: such agreement on the meaning and disagreement on the phrasing comes to be.

mn103:7.12.eng: But the phrasing is a minor matter.

mn103:7.13.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about something so minor.’

mn103:7.14.pli: Iti suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretabbaṃ, duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretabbaṃ.
mn103:7.14.eng: So you should remember what has been correctly memorized as correctly memorized and what has been incorrectly memorized as incorrectly memorized.

mn103:7.15.pli: Suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretvā duggahitaṃ duggahitato dhāretvā yo dhammo yo vinayo so bhāsitabbo.
mn103:7.15.eng: Remembering this, you should speak on the teaching and the training.

mn103:8.2.pli: ‘imesaṃ kho āyasmantānaṃ atthato ceva sameti byañjanato ca sametī’ti, tattha yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:8.2.eng: ‘These two venerables agree on both the meaning and the phrasing.’ So you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable and say to them:

mn103:8.3.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato ceva sameti, byañjanato ca sameti.
mn103:8.3.eng: ‘The venerables agree on both the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:8.4.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:8.5.pli: yathā atthato ceva sameti byañjanato ca sameti.
mn103:8.5.eng: they come to agree on the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:8.6.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:8.7.pli: Athāparesaṃ ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:8.7.eng: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:

mn103:8.8.pli: ‘āyasmantānaṃ kho atthato ceva sameti byañjanato ca sameti.
mn103:8.8.eng: ‘The venerables agree on both the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:8.9.eng: But the venerables should know that this is how

mn103:8.10.pli: yathā atthato ceva sameti byañjanato ca sameti.
mn103:8.10.eng: they come to agree on the meaning and the phrasing.

mn103:8.11.eng: Please don’t get into a dispute about this.’

mn103:8.12.eng: So you should remember what has been correctly memorized as correctly memorized.

mn103:8.13.pli: Suggahitaṃ suggahitato dhāretvā yo dhammo yo vinayo so bhāsitabbo.
mn103:8.13.eng: Remembering this, you should speak on the teaching and the training.

mn103:9.1.pli: Tesañca vo, bhikkhave, samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ siyā aññatarassa bhikkhuno āpatti siyā vītikkamo,
mn103:9.1.eng: As you train in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, one of the mendicants might commit an offense or transgression.
mn103:9.1.comm: Namely, a  transgression against the Monastic Code, the Vinaya. Such offences are a collective ethical standard that require other monastics to resolve, at least by hearing a confession.

mn103:10.1.pli: tatra, bhikkhave, na codanāya taritabbaṃ. Puggalo upaparikkhitabbo:
mn103:10.1.eng: In such a case, you should not be in a hurry to accuse them. The individual should be examined like this:
mn103:10.1.comm: Vinaya is not meant to be applied legalistically or cruelly, but to uplift and reform. | Punctuation in Mahāsaṅgīti is incorrect. The following iti belongs on this line, as shown in the repetition below.

mn103:10.2.pli: ‘iti mayhañca avihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa anupaghāto, paro hi puggalo akkodhano anupanāhī adaḷhadiṭṭhī suppaṭinissaggī, sakkomi cāhaṃ etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetun’ti.
mn103:10.2.eng: ‘I won’t be troubled and the other individual won’t be hurt, for they’re not irritable and acrimonious. They don’t hold fast to their views, but let them go easily. I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’

mn103:10.3.eng: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.
mn103:10.3.comm: If the problem can be resolved without resorting to legal proceedings, it should.

mn103:11.2.pli: ‘mayhaṃ kho avihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa upaghāto, paro hi puggalo kodhano upanāhī adaḷhadiṭṭhī suppaṭinissaggī, sakkomi cāhaṃ etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetuṃ.
mn103:11.2.eng: ‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and acrimonious. However, they don’t hold fast to their views, but let them go easily. I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.

mn103:11.3.pli: Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ yadidaṃ—parassa puggalassa upaghāto.
mn103:11.3.eng: But for the other individual to get hurt is a minor matter.

mn103:11.5.pli: svāhaṃ sakkomi etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetun’ti.
mn103:11.5.eng: that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’

mn103:11.6.eng: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.

mn103:12.2.pli: ‘mayhaṃ kho vihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa anupaghāto. Paro hi puggalo akkodhano anupanāhī daḷhadiṭṭhī duppaṭinissaggī, sakkomi cāhaṃ etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetuṃ.
mn103:12.2.eng: ‘I will be troubled but the other individual won’t be hurt, for they’re not irritable and acrimonious. However, they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. Nevertheless, I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.

mn103:12.3.eng: But for me to be troubled is a minor matter.

mn103:12.5.pli: svāhaṃ sakkomi etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetun’ti.
mn103:12.5.eng: that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’

mn103:12.6.eng: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.

mn103:13.2.pli: ‘mayhañca kho vihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa upaghāto. Paro hi puggalo kodhano upanāhī daḷhadiṭṭhī duppaṭinissaggī, sakkomi cāhaṃ etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetuṃ.
mn103:13.2.eng: ‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and acrimonious. And they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. Nevertheless, I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.

mn103:13.3.pli: Appamattakaṃ kho panetaṃ yadidaṃ—mayhañca vihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa upaghāto.
mn103:13.3.eng: But for me to be troubled and the other individual to get hurt is a minor matter.

mn103:13.5.pli: svāhaṃ sakkomi etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetun’ti.
mn103:13.5.eng: that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’

mn103:13.6.eng: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.

mn103:14.2.pli: ‘mayhañca kho vihesā bhavissati parassa ca puggalassa upaghāto. Paro hi puggalo kodhano upanāhī daḷhadiṭṭhī duppaṭinissaggī, na cāhaṃ sakkomi etaṃ puggalaṃ akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpetun’ti.
mn103:14.2.eng: ‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and acrimonious. And they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. I cannot draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’

mn103:14.3.eng: Don’t underestimate the value of equanimity regarding such an individual.
mn103:14.3.comm: Wisdom knows that sometimes there is nothing to be done. That doesn’t mean one gives up, but rather, that sometimes patience is the best way. Note that this is the last option, however, and gentle intervention is always preferred.

mn103:15.1.pli: Tesañca vo, bhikkhave, samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ aññamaññassa vacīsaṃhāro uppajjeyya diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi.
mn103:15.1.eng: As you train in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, the sides might continue to bring up settled issues with each other, with contempt for each other’s views, resentful, bitter, and exasperated.
mn103:15.1.comm: Readings include vacīsaṁsāro, vacīsaṁhāro, and vacīsaṅkhāro. Vacīsaṁsāro is found, without recorded variants, in the parallel passage at AN 2.63:1.1. The commentary here glosses with vacanasañcāro, while the subcommentary to AN 2.63 has pavattamānā, both of which support the dominant reading vacīsaṁsāro. Their explanations differ, however as the commentary here explains as spreading rumors from one place to another, while at AN 2.63 it is said to be ongoing arguing. Since the normal meaning of saṁsāra is “endless ongoing”, and since, in both MN and AN, this follows a passage where disputes were supposed to have been settled, perhaps the sense is “continuing to bring up matters that have been settled”.

mn103:15.2.pli: Tattha ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:15.2.eng: In this case you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable among those who side with one party and say to them:

mn103:15.3.pli: ‘yaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ aññamaññassa vacīsaṃhāro uppanno diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi, taṃ jānamāno samaṇo garaheyyā’ti.
mn103:15.3.eng: ‘Reverend, as we were training, the sides continued to bring up settled issues with each other. If the Ascetic knew about this, would he criticize it?’

mn103:15.4.pli: Sammā byākaramāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ byākareyya:
mn103:15.4.eng: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:

mn103:15.5.pli: ‘yaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ aññamaññassa vacīsaṃhāro uppanno diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi, taṃ jānamāno samaṇo garaheyyāti.

mn103:15.6.pli: Etaṃ panāvuso, dhammaṃ appahāya nibbānaṃ sacchikareyyā’ti.
mn103:15.6.eng: ‘But without giving that up, reverend, can one realize extinguishment?’

mn103:15.7.pli: Sammā byākaramāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ byākareyya:
mn103:15.7.eng: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:

mn103:15.8.pli: ‘etaṃ, āvuso, dhammaṃ appahāya na nibbānaṃ sacchikareyyā’ti.

mn103:16.1.pli: Athāparesaṃ ekatopakkhikānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yaṃ bhikkhuṃ suvacataraṃ maññeyyātha, so upasaṅkamitvā evamassa vacanīyo:
mn103:16.1.eng: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:

mn103:16.2.pli: ‘yaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ aññamaññassa vacīsaṃhāro uppanno diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi, taṃ jānamāno samaṇo garaheyyā’ti.
mn103:16.2.eng: ‘Reverend, as we were training, the sides continued to bring up settled issues with each other. If the Ascetic knew about this, would he criticize it?’

mn103:16.3.pli: Sammā byākaramāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ byākareyya:
mn103:16.3.eng: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:

mn103:16.4.pli: ‘yaṃ no, āvuso, amhākaṃ samaggānaṃ sammodamānānaṃ avivadamānānaṃ sikkhataṃ aññamaññassa vacīsaṃhāro uppanno diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi taṃ jānamāno samaṇo garaheyyāti.

mn103:16.5.pli: Etaṃ panāvuso, dhammaṃ appahāya nibbānaṃ sacchikareyyā’ti.
mn103:16.5.eng: ‘But without giving that up, reverend, can one realize extinguishment?’

mn103:16.6.pli: Sammā byākaramāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ byākareyya:
mn103:16.6.eng: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:

mn103:16.7.pli: ‘etaṃ kho, āvuso, dhammaṃ appahāya na nibbānaṃ sacchikareyyā’ti.

mn103:17.1.pli: Tañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ pare evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
mn103:17.1.eng: If others should ask that mendicant:

mn103:17.2.pli: ‘āyasmatā no ete bhikkhū akusalā vuṭṭhāpetvā kusale patiṭṭhāpitā’ti?
mn103:17.2.eng: ‘Were you the venerable who drew those mendicants away from the unskillful and established them in the skillful?’

mn103:17.3.pli: Sammā byākaramāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ byākareyya:
mn103:17.3.eng: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:

mn103:17.4.pli: ‘idhāhaṃ, āvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃ, tassa me bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi, tāhaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ abhāsiṃ.
mn103:17.4.eng: ‘Well, reverends, I approached the Buddha. He taught me the Dhamma. After hearing that teaching I explained it to those mendicants.

mn103:17.5.pli: Taṃ te bhikkhū dhammaṃ sutvā akusalā vuṭṭhahiṃsu, kusale patiṭṭhahiṃsū’ti.
mn103:17.5.eng: When those mendicants heard that teaching they were drawn away from the unskillful and established in the skillful.’

mn103:17.6.pli: Evaṃ byākaramāno kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na ceva attānaṃ ukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaroti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchatī”ti.
mn103:17.6.eng: Answering in this way, that mendicant doesn’t glorify themselves or put others down. They answer in line with the teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism.”

mn103:17.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn103:17.8.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn103:17.8.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
